captions.text: I was bullied a lot, and I never had much self-confidence. I never felt like I was a good enough person.
In life, I have low self-esteem. I don't really talk to people. I don't interact with people. In life, I'm what you would say an outsider.
Through cosplay I could become these characters. I could live vicariously with how cool they were. It seems like a lot of people feel the need to become someone else, to strengthen themselves.
People are going to judge me. Probably think I'm a loser or something.
I've been to every flea market, every Goodwill, every craft shop, every fashion district, every corner of the internet to make this costume.
I feel fairly anxious because some times you're really not sure how it's gonna turn out until you all put it together.
And really part of what makes cosplay so beautiful is how people can interpret curves, and strange clothing pieces that wouldn't even exist in our world.
As I walk down the halls of the convention center, I felt very nervous. People looked at me.
But they didn't look at me in a judgmental way
In the cosplay community there is just so much support and love and such abundance that it's really hard not to feel moved.
It's a community where they create a safe space for you to just be who you are.
Cosplay really can be for anybody. If you have passion and a will to bring something you love so dearly that there really is no excuse to not try it out.
You're there to just express what you love. What cosplay does is it gives you that confidence. And it makes it ok to like things that nobody else does.
Opens you up to friendships, to people who love the same stuff you love. And you don't have to be judged. And that's the greatest thing about cosplay.

comments.text:
As a beginner cosplayer with a lot of judgemental people in my school i 
found this video really inspiring to not be ashamed of the enjoyment i get 
seeing cosplays of my favourite characters and to really continue with it. 
I finished my first cosplay a few weeks ago and i really love it but 
whenever i post a picture of it i get nervous incase the people i go to 
school with and that always judge me will start to ruin my confidence all 
over again. But by watching this and seeing the joy on peoples faces in 
public as well as the fact they have gone through what i am is a real 
confidence booster for me. And seeing not only anime characters there but 
PM from homestuck really makes me smile. ﻿

comments.text:
I've been cosplaying since last summer when I went to my first convention, 
and I honestly didn't know what I was doing in my school uniform skirt and 
a 10th doctor tshirt and a trenchcoat meeting John Barrrowman. Now, I'm 
painting my entire body gray to be Vriska Serket for just one simple photo. 
Cosplay has made me escape reality if I'm ever feeling down, and it has 
helped me to make so many new friends. If you ever feel like you aren't the 
right age, gender, race, body type, or anything else to cosplay your 
favorite character, then cosplay anyway. People aren't going to put you 
down for cosplaying, YOU the one putting yourself down the most.﻿

comments.author: Ele Bubu

comments.text:
I don't really cosplay much as a fan. I'd like to, but I don't have the 
energy to devote to completely becoming someone or something else. I stick 
to characters who look like me for the most part. I've been George from 
Paradise Kiss, and I'm supposed to do Hideyoshi Kinoshita from Baka and 
Test either this year or next, but my most used costume is Leo from Fairy 
Tail. It's a nice suit and tie outfit, and really the only odd touch is the 
wig and a few pieces of jewelry. I wore the outfit sans wig to my best 
friend's sister's wedding.
I'm a fan because I was bullied when I was younger, and I was awkward as a 
kid, but through my anime hobby I've become more confident and personable. 
If I cosplay, I do so because I want to see people smile. And it really is 
a nice community despite all the negative stereotypes and everything people 
say when they think no one's looking (4chan).﻿

comments.author: KC jepp

comments.text:
That's a horrible thing to say. Firstly, they weren't chubby, and secondly 
how are they losers? Look at these incredible talents they have. Doing what 
they're doing takes hard work, skill, and work ethic. These are traits a 
lot of people lack nowadays. I think that these people are admirable, and 
instead of trying to tear them down, we should be trying to not only find 
these qualities in ourselves, but also help others to achieve these 
qualities.

Hmmm try something simple. Find a character that you like that has "normal" 
looking clothes, it'll be a lot easier to find the things that you need for 
your cosplay as they'll just be regular clothing, and it'll probably be a 
lot more comfortable than say a huge bulky battle armour cosplay. Good luck 
:)

I'm cosplaying for the first time this summer. I know my parents weren't

feet) and he had the same hair color and length, and surprisingly, style, 
so I was like why not? Now I preparing the costume and to go to my first 
Anime Convention. I super pumped! (Cosplaying Edward Elric. He's in the 
video if you watch closely. :)﻿

comments.text:
I don't know if anyone would agree with me on that but I think it's kinda 
like the furry community. Fursuiters suit up because of various reasons.
We're not someone who likes to have s*x with animals. That's totally not 
the case and a false assumption made about the furry community.
We can also suit up just to have fun. If we meet other fursuiters, then we 
have even more fun.
what I can totally tell is that suiting up in a fursuit and cosplaying 
(I've never done it just saying it from what I've been seeing so far) is 
both a really fun thing to do.

We're just like the cosplayers. We're full of love and support and 
especially when one of our fandom members is in pain.﻿
